timeline.bodyText: Instead of saying latest version, specify the version number.
timeline.author: srnagar
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,8 @@
 # Release History
 
-## 4.1.0-beta.1 (Unreleased)
+## 4.1.0 (2020-01-07)
+- Fixes the logic of `getKeyId()` method in `KeyEncryptionKeyClient` and `KeyEncryptionKeyAsyncClient` to ensure key id is available in all scenarios.
+- Update azure-core dependency to latest version.

timeline.author: srnagar
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,7 @@
 # Release History
 
-## 4.0.0-beta.8 (Unreleased)
+## 4.0.0 (2020-01-07)
+- Update azure-core dependency to latest version.

timeline.bodyText: Also, update the version_client.txt and remove this dependency. I believe this was the only place this dependency was used.
timeline.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: I am assuming  you mean external_dependencies.txt
replies.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText:
Track 1 KV still references commons-codec.
So, cannot remove from external_dependencies.txt too,
replies.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: So nothing should ever be deleted from external_dependencies.txt unless you know for an absolute fact it isn't being used by anywhere else. There are several data track libraries that require this dependency. In my comment above I put in a couple of commands that can be run from the command line to check, in the future.
replies.author: JimSuplizio

timeline.bodyText:
Your PR is failing because you removed an external_dependency that is used by other libraries. In the future, if you're curious as to whether a dependency is being used you can run one of two quick commands to check:

From a powershell 6 window, in the root of the enlistment run .\eng\pom_file_version_scanner.ps1 (thought this is only going to tell you after you remove the entry)
For something quick and dirty on Windows you can just run findstr /spin /c:"commons-codec:commons-codec" pom*.xml
timeline.author: JimSuplizio

replies.bodyText: yep, I already reverted this change
replies.author: g2vinay
